events.title: National Conservatory of Music
events.summary: In 1901, Ponce enrolled at the National Conservatory of Music, gaining a reputation as a pianist and composer. He studied there until 1903 before returning to Aguascalientes.
events.fun_version: In 1901, Ponce enrolled at the National Conservatory of Music. He became a big deal as a pianist and composer, spicing up the music scene. After studying there until 1903, he returned to Aguascalientes.

events.title: Advanced Musical Studies in Italy
events.summary: In 1904, Ponce traveled to Italy to pursue advanced studies at the Conservatorio Giovanni Battista Martini in Bologna, furthering his musical education abroad.
events.fun_version: In 1904, Ponce traveled to Italy to study at the prestigious Conservatorio Giovanni Battista Martini in Bologna.

events.title: Studying in Germany
events.summary: From 1906 to 1908, Ponce continued his education in Germany at the Stern Conservatory in Berlin under the tutelage of Martin Krause, polishing his skills as a pianist and composer.
events.fun_version: From 1906 to 1908, Ponce continued his education in Germany at the Stern Conservatory in Berlin, deciding to spice things up by studying piano. His teacher, Martin Krause, probably thought ‘Stern Conservatory’ meant he had to read the stars while playing—thankfully, Ponce just focused on polishing his skills as a pianist and composer while not hitting the wrong keys!

events.title: Teaching at the National Conservatory
events.summary: After his years abroad, Ponce returned to Mexico to teach piano and music history at the National Conservatory of Music between 1909 and 1915, and again from 1917 to 1922, except for a two-year period spent in Havana, Cuba.
events.fun_version: Ponce took a dramatic detour from a globe-trotting piano recital to doing his best impersonation of a musical teacher in Mexico! Between 1909 and 1915, he was the ultimate music guru at the National Conservatory of Music, sprinkling musical magic like confetti. But hold onto your hats — he traded in his maracas for a suitcase as he hopped over to Havana, Cuba, for two glorious years. Just when you thought he'd settled in, he returned in style from 1917 to 1922, probably with a fanfare instead of a welcome!

events.title: Composition of 'Estrellita'
events.summary: In 1912, Ponce composed his renowned piece 'Estrellita', which is often misinterpreted as a love song. This work plays a significant role in his legacy as a composer.
events.fun_version: In 1912, Ponce whipped up his famous tune 'Estrellita', which some people mistakenly think is a mushy love song. This work plays a significant role in his legacy as a composer, shining bright like a disco ball at a wedding!

events.title: Concert at the Arbeau Theater
events.summary: That same year, Ponce held a notable concert of Mexican popular music at the Arbeau Theater, which was controversial but marked an important moment in the evolution of national song.
events.fun_version: That same year, Ponce threw a notable concert of Mexican popular music at the Arbeau Theater, which stirred up enough controversy to make a soap opera plot look like a kiddie show! This important moment in the evolution of national song was like a taco stand at a vegan festival; it caused quite the stir!

events.title: National Science and Arts Prize
events.summary: In 1947, Ponce was honored with the National Science and Arts Prize in recognition of his contributions to Mexican music and culture.
events.fun_version: In 1947, Ponce won the National Science and Arts Prize in recognition of his incredible contributions to Mexican music and culture—because apparently, if you play the guitar while juggling maracas, you’re a scientific genius!

works.title: Preludios y fuga de un tema de J.S. Bach
Petite suite dans le style ancien
Variations on a Theme of Cabezon
